claim: Early Eastern Canadian Natives language would have use of the letter B.

supporting.text: The Algonquian languages, spoken by many Eastern Canadian Natives, do not include the phoneme /b/ in their phonetic inventory.

attacks.text: The Algonquian languages, spoken by many Eastern Canadian Natives, do not include the phoneme /b/ in their phonetic inventory.
Some Algonquian dialects may have borrowed the /b/ phoneme through contact with European languages.
Borrowed phonemes typically appear in loanwords and do not integrate fully into the native phonetic inventory.
There might be undocumented or extinct Eastern Canadian Native languages that included the /b/ phoneme.
Linguistic reconstructions and historical records strongly suggest the absence of /b/ in early Eastern Canadian Native languages.

supporting.text: Linguistic studies of early Eastern Canadian Native languages show a lack of labial stops like /b/, which are uncommon in indigenous North American languages.

attacks.text: Linguistic studies of early Eastern Canadian Native languages show a lack of labial stops like /b/, which are uncommon in indigenous North American languages.
Some Algonquian languages, such as Mi'kmaq, have been documented with labial sounds, though not necessarily the exact /b/ stop.
The presence of labial sounds in some languages does not imply the use of the specific phoneme /b/, which remains rare in Eastern Canadian Native languages.
Early European contact may have introduced loanwords containing /b/, influencing some Eastern Canadian Native languages.
Loanword influence is sporadic and does not reflect the native phonological inventory of early Eastern Canadian Native languages.

supporting.text: Historical records and transcriptions of early Eastern Canadian Native languages do not document the use of the letter B or its corresponding sound.

attacks.text: Historical records and transcriptions of early Eastern Canadian Native languages do not document the use of the letter B or its corresponding sound.
Some early transcriptions may have been influenced by European biases, leading to potential omissions or inaccuracies in documenting certain sounds like 'B'.
Linguistic studies show that Eastern Canadian Native languages had phonetic structures that could accommodate sounds similar to 'B', even if not directly documented.
Oral traditions and modern reconstructions suggest that some Eastern Canadian Native languages might have had sounds resembling 'B', though not explicitly recorded.
Comparative linguistics with related languages indicates that the absence of 'B' in documented records does not necessarily mean it was absent in spoken forms.

supporting.text: The phonological systems of Eastern Canadian Native languages, such as Mi'kmaq and Innu-aimun, primarily feature sounds like /m/, /p/, and /n/, but not /b/.

attacks.text: The phonological systems of Eastern Canadian Native languages, such as Mi'kmaq and Innu-aimun, primarily feature sounds like /m/, /p/, and /n/, but not /b/.
Some Eastern Canadian Native languages, like Malecite-Passamaquoddy, have documented instances of /b/ in loanwords from European languages.
Loanwords do not reflect the native phonological system of a language, as they are borrowed from external sources.
Historical records suggest that some Eastern Canadian Native languages may have had /b/ as an allophone of /p/ in certain phonetic environments.
Allophonic variation does not imply the phoneme /b/ was part of the language's core phonological inventory.

supporting.text: Comparative linguistics indicates that the /b/ sound is rare in indigenous languages of the Americas, including those in Eastern Canada.

attacks.text: Comparative linguistics indicates that the /b/ sound is rare in indigenous languages of the Americas, including those in Eastern Canada.
Some Eastern Canadian Native languages, like Innu-aimun, have borrowed words with /b/ sounds from European languages, introducing the sound post-contact.
Borrowed words do not reflect the original phonological inventory of the language, so they are not evidence of pre-contact /b/ usage.
The rarity of /b/ does not imply its complete absence, as some indigenous languages in other regions (e.g., Mapudungun in South America) have /b/ sounds.
Mapudungun is geographically and linguistically distant from Eastern Canadian languages, making it irrelevant to the claim.
